Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 02:35AM dreniger wrote: It's true, I guess I have assumed that the cancer (if it's even there) would grow slowly. And since there are only 5 weeks left of chemo for my sister, I've been thinking that if I need treatment, I could wait that long. I guess I'm being naive to think that. I realize that it may be benign, and certainly hope it is.The radiologist certainly believes that it's cancer, and he could be wrong. The fact that they went ahead and scheduled me with a surgeon seems significant to me. Also of concern ~ 2 of my father's 3 sisters have had breast cancer, 1 of my 2 sisters has breast cancer, 1 of my four female cousins on my father's side has had breast cancer. My father has had colon cancer, and his father died of colon cancer at age 59. My sisters and I have all 3 had precancerous polyps removed from our colons, and we all have colonoscopies every 5 years (started having them in our 30s). One of my dad's sisters who had breast cancer, also had pancreatic cancer (and survived!). My father had one sister who did not have breast cancer, but her daughter did. Although she's a generation farther removed, one of my aunts who had breast cancer also has a granddaughter who had breast cancer (in her 20s). My sister's oncologist was somewhat alarmed by the amount of cancer, and especially breast cancer, that is in our family. She did have genetic testing, which indicated that she does not have the gene mutation. We were very thankful for that news. I know I can't make real plans until after the biopsy, and hopefully at that time I won't need to make such plans at all. But with what appears to be a strong possiblity that I may have BC, I want to think ahead as much as possible. It seems important to investigate the hospitals in my area, and select the best one for possible treatment. And I guess I feel like my sister and I should discuss future possibilities now, while my head is clear. I believe I'll be able to discuss it easily following a diagnosis, should there be one. But I can't guarantee that. So I think I should consider possibilities now, while I don't have the stress of a diagnosis. Then if I do have cancer, some things will already have been considered and possibliy decided. And if the lump is benign, we'll just party. Hard :) I haven't felt any sense of panic. I've actually been very calm. Much more so than my husband. Just want to consider the possibilities and be as prepared as I can be regardless of the outcome of the biopsy. Thank you all for your wishes for my sister and myself. She's the baby (just turned 54), and is very special. Unfortunately, she's unable to go to Michigan for treatment due to her job. She's the director of a very large revenue facility in Madison, and oversees 19 hospitals in 5 states. I think she could delegate a little more to her CFO, COO, etc., but she has to handle her work in the way she thinks best. Now that the AC chemo is over and she's tolerating the Taxol (sp?) a little better, she's trying to work a few days a week in her office. Otherwise, she works at home. She has developed neuropathy in her feet since starting the Taxol, and her oncologist advised her to keep her feet up as much as possible. She really does need someone her to do laundry, clean the litter box, cook. You know, pretty much everything. She also doesn't want to leave her medical team. She's being treated at the University of WI Carbone Cancer Center. She believes that the care she is currently getting is superior to what she would get in Michigan. While I live in Grand Rapids, and have access to excellent health care, if she went back she would prefer to be in Battle Creek, with my parents. I'm not familiar with their hospitals or cancer treatment options. But she does believe that she currently has the best care possible. I'd LOVE to take her back to Grand Rapids with me! I'll certainly give further consideration to the ramifications of delaying treatment, and will talk to the surgeon about it. I think I'll talk to the UW Hospital Program Manager (R.N.) as well. And obviously, no decisions can be made until after the biopsy, when I find out what I'm dealing with, if anything. I hope I don't sound like a hysterical woman assuming the worst. I'm trying to be rational, and consider my options if things turn out badly. I think if things turn out for the best, I'll ask my husband to come to Madison for a weekend, and we'll see if can get my sister out on the town for an evening! Denise (sorry this became so long and involved. I hestitate to talk to my sister too much about this, because she's already quite stressed and I don't want to add to that. I really don't know anyone here in Madison, other than a few of her coworkers I've met. I think talking this out is good, and I'm so glad I can do it here. Thank you!)
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 01:23AM dreniger wrote: From what I've read, I'm glad that I'm having a SNB rather than ALND. At this point, that's my preference. I was told that I'll hear the results of the biopsy within 48 hours, and they do it with a phone call, which is fine with me. I have no need for anyone to hold my hand while they give me the news. Basically, I've pretty much been given the news already. So I expect the call to confirm what the radiologist has already said. Change can be bad, change can be good. While some changes will likely be pretty unpleasant, I plan on my life changing for as long as I live, and I plan on changing for the good.  Thanks for adding to my increasing pile of knowledge :)
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 01:21AM dreniger wrote: Had my US-guided core biopsy this morning. It was a breeze. Barely felt the small injections to numb the area. Each time he took a sample, he counted down from three, and then I heard a click as he took the sample. Sounded like an ear piercing gun like they use at the mall. I felt a slight movement, no pain. He was satisfied that he got 5 good samples. On today's US, the mass measured 1.26x1.24cm. Again, the lymph nodes did not look enlarged. I should get results tomorrow or Wednesday. He said again that it has all the characteristics of a malignancy, but of course nothing can be confirmed until the pathology report is back. It's been nearly 11 hours since the biopsy. I used the ice pack 15 minutes out of every hour. I've had no pain except for once when I bent over to pick something up, a slight twinge. I went out to lunch with my husband, came home and did a few things, took my sister out to dinner tonight. I feel great tonight. Hoping to get results tomorrow after 11.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 11:51PM dreniger wrote: They did specifically say core biopsy and sentinel node biopsy. When the radiologist talked with me, he said that the lymph nodes do not look enlarged, which is he was happy about. Also, the lump in my right brease, which is what started all this, appears to clearly be fibroid. No biopsy for that one. I was surprised too, when I was told that I would be having a sentinel node biopsy, since he had told me that the nodes did not appear to be enlarged. It was the Nurse Program Manager, reading the radiologist's order, who told me I would also be having the SNB. I took very complete notes while talking to both the radiologist and the Nurse Program Manager. Unfortunately, I can't give my husband a big, bear hug when we talk. Our talks have to be over the phone for now. He's in Michigan, while I'm in Madison, WI helping my younger sister as she goes through her treatment for breast cancer (stage III). He has business in Chicago on Friday, so he's coming to Madison after his meetings, and will stay til Tuesday morning. His original plan was to leave Monday morning. He changed his plans after my mammogram and US, so that he will be here for my biopsy. While I'm in Madison, we see each other every 6-8 weeks. Sometimes for a day or two, in December a couple different family members came for a week each so that I could be with my family for 2 weeks. I do have a sister and a niece who each have some more vacation time available now that it's a new year. My other sister has said she'd like to come to Madison for a few days when our younger sister has surgery. Probably late March. And my sister has said she thinks she may be able to get by on her own after she has recovered from surgery, during her 6 weeks of radiation. Of course that remains to be seen.  Again, thanks for helping me think and talk this through. Although I'm feeling calm, I know there are things I'm not thinking of, and perspective I don't have. And honestly, I'd rather come here and talk with women who have been where I am, than Google symptoms looking for something I may or may not have.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 08:24PM dreniger wrote: I just got a call back from the Nurse Program Manager. She verified that the SNB will indeed be at the time of surgery, not at the time of the core biopsy. So you were absolutely right, Beacon. I'm so glad that you brought this up. It's something I wouldn't have thought to ask, because I don't know the normal timing of the procedures. While I've been with my sister throughout her treatment, I was not here during the weeks of diagnositc procedures. When she talked about the SNB, I didn't bat an eyelash. I know what it is, and it didn't occur to me that it wouldn't make sense to do it during the core biopsy. Let me clarify. I know about the dye, and how the sentinel node is determined. I did not know that it's actually a surgical procedure. So I did not understand it as well as I thought I did.  I asked the PM just how sure the radiologist really is that this lump is cancer. She said that he talked to her after I met with her, and he told her he's sure it's cancer. Then she look up the actual notes he wrote in my chart, and quoted from it, "the mass has all the characteristics of a malignancy." She said that the biopsy is obviously necessary, but they're already planning for it to be malignant. He was are sure as he could be that it is. She also said that their policy is to be very frank and honest with their patients up front. They don't want to soft pedal, and then have the patient be blindsided. That's exactly what I want as well. She also indicated that the ultrasound under my arm did not show lymph nodes appearing to be enlarged. Obvioulsy they'll know more after the SNB, but so far the radiologist feels optimistic about that. What they have planned for me at this point is: core biopsy, surgical consultation at which time they will tell me whether they believe I should have chemo before surgery, after surgery, or even whether I should have chemo at all, then surgery (possibly lumpectomy, but will know more after looking at pathology), then definitely radiation. I asked her if radiation is standard following a lumpectomy, and she said that it is. Each time I say "she" I'm referring to the Nurse Program Manager. When I say "he" I'm referring to the radiologist. So I'm a little more informed. Not anything I didn't expect from my discussions following the US, other than my misunderstanding about the SNB. But now I've heard it said with no doubt about the results. I know exactly what they think I'm dealing with. So I'm ready to move forward and get this taken care of, and get on with my life. I've been told breast cancer will change my life, and I'm not sure exactly how, other than the treatment. Guess I'll probably find out soon. And despite the radiologist's confidence that this is malignant, I am aware that it's not really cancer til the biopsy says it's cancer. So I'm not actually going to say that I have breast cancer until after the biopsy results are in. At this point I have a suspicious mass in my left breast. I'll be hanging around for quite a while, it looks like. All of your help has been amazing and appreciated. I'm thankful that you're all here, so willing to help and to share information, and I hope that I some point I can do the same for someone else. Denise
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: dreniger wrote: I'm not officially diagnosed yet, but am pretty sure I know what the biopsy results will be.  Found a lump in my right breast a few weeks ago. Had diagnostic mammogram Thursday, during which the lump appeared to fibroid. But also sound a mass in left breast that looks suspicious. Immediately had ultrasound of both breasts. Again, lump in right appears to be fibroid. Lump in left "very concerning." I asked the tech to turn the monitor so I could watch as she did the US, so I got a good look at it. Her only comment was that she would come back in a few minutes with the radiologist, so he could talk to me about a plan. He came in looking very grave, and said he was concerned about the mass in my left breast. I asked how concerned he was, and he said "very." Poor guy, I felt like hugging him and telling him it would be okay. So I'm scheduled for a core biopsy on Monday, 2/6. I have an appt to meet with the surgeon on Monday 2/13. I'm from Michigan, but have been in Madison, WI since Sept. caring for my younger sister who was diagnosed with BC in Aug 2011. She has 5 rounds of chemo to go, then surgery, then 6-8 weeks of daily radiation. I'm currently trying to decide (if I do indeed have BC), whether to have treatment in WI or MI. I can receive excellent care in either place. My concern is my sister. She has no other family in Madison. In MI, I have my husband, 2 adult sons and 1 daughter-in-law, another sister and her family, and my parents. And a wonderful church family. I'm leaning toward delaying treatment at least until my sister's chemo is over. Then she'll have 4 weeks rest before surgery. She should feel pretty good during those 4 weeks. My other sister can stay with her for a week the time of her surgery, and a niece can stay with her the following week. She believes she'll be able to take care of herself during her radiation. My plan was to be here through June, which is probably when she'll be finished with radiation. Lots of decisions to make. Meanwhile, my poor husband and sons are in Michigan, a little freaked out. The mass is only 1.2 x 1 cm. So if it turns out that the lymph nodes are okay, I would be at Stage 1. And there there are the other details ~ hormone receptors, HER, etc. Ah, lots to think about. Right now, my personal biggest concern is my sister (she's stage 3). But I need to consider the feelings of my husband and sons. I'd prefer to delay treatment, regardless of the outcome. My family wants me to come home. My sister is leaning toward me going home for treatment, should that become necessary. I guess time will tell. I'll know more after 2/6, and can make a more informed decision. Denise Dx 2/7/2012, ILC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 2/28/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 4/16/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 7/12/2012 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 03:25AM dreniger wrote: Interesting article. Thanks! I was under the impression that ALND was diagnostic. I was reading on the Treatment & Side Effects page (under Surgery -> Lymph Node Removal) about ALND. It is under the treatment section, but it refers to ALND as being performed to help doctors figure out extent of cancer involvement. Although it's surgical, I took that to mean the examination of the lymph nodes was for diagnostic reasons. That they're removed before it's known whether they're cancerous. Either way, I'd prefer not to have ALND, for any reason. I've heard enough about the risks of Lymphedema to know that I want to keep that risk as low as possible. I suppose there could be a scenario where it may be the right option. I hope it doesn't come to that.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 08:07PM dreniger wrote: Thanks so much for all of the encouragement and information. I'm doing very well, as far as not borrowing trouble from tomorrow. While I know the odds are not in my favor, I'm not going to assume that I have cancer. I'll accept the results of the biopsy, good or bad, and move on from there. Something is happening that has really caught me off guard. My husband is convinced that I have cancer. Because the radiologist seems quite sure that it's cancer, and they've scheduled me with the surgeon already, along with the family history, he believes it's cancer and that the biopsy is basically a formality. He's as upset as if I had gotten a diagnosis already. He thinks that I'm in denial because I won't say I have cancer. I know he's just dealing with the  findings on the mammogram and US, and he thinks the radiologist's words to me were as good as a diagnosis. Also, his first wife (they divorced when their children were small) passed away about 10 years ago from breast cancer. Although they were divorced, they had a fairly amicable relationship because of the kids. So I'm sure that he has some fear because of that. But ~ I'm concerned about him scaring my sons. They're adults, 23 and 29, so I'm not worried about the kind of fear and inability to understand that a small child would have. But we're very, very close, and they were quite upset when I told them I'm going in for a biopsy. They were very shaken in August when my sister was diagnosed, and I know they fear the same for me. But they're pretty level-headed. I'm just concerned that my husband will convince them that I have cancer and add to their worry prematurely. They're all in Michigan, and they talk nearly every day. I've explained the facts. I guess I just need to trust that rather than him adding to their worry, they'll actually help relieve his. It's funny how people react so strongly before I've even had a biopsy. I feel almost guilty that I'm having a great day, and enjoying the sunshine and my reading, while my husband is hundreds of miles away worrying himself sick.  Ah well, the biopsy is next Monday, I'm supposed to hear results within 48 hours, and meeting with the surgeon is the following Monday, if necessary. We'll all have answers soon enough. While I'm waiting to go in for the biopsy, if anyone cares to share any information about what to expect, that would be great. I'm having a core biopsy and sentinel node biopsy. All they told me is to not wear deodorant, wear a supportive bra, and that I would hear results within 48 hours. My sister said that her core biopsy was more painful than the earlier fine needle biopsy. I have a pretty high pain tolerance, so I'm not freaking out about that.Other than that, is there anything else I should be aware of? Any questions I should be asking? Will I get any type of information at all that day? Life, family, emotions.......strange stuff. Thanks for being such a great, collective sounding board!
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 02:53AM dreniger wrote: Marie, the radiologist did indicate strongly that he believes I have BC. Even as the tech was leaving the room after the US, she said the radiologist would come in a few minutes to talk to me about a plan. Can it so clearly be cancer that sometimes there's no doubt when they see it, even for the tech? When the radiologist came in to talk to me, he obviously was giving me bad news. He looked like he was delivering a diagnosis, although I knew that wasn't possible. Grave is the only word that describes his countenance. Not what I expect from someone who is talking about remote possibilities. He said that he was concerned about the lump in my left breast, and I would be scheduled for a biopsy. I asked him how concerned he was, and he said "very." I asked how big the lump is, and he said that on the US it appears to be 1.2cm x 1cm. He asked if I had any other questions, which I did not. I did ask the tech to turn the monitor so I could see it during the US, and to explain what she was doing, which she did. I clearly saw the shape, color (black during the first part, no blood flow when she changed the settings to show color for blood flow). I commented to her about things I was unable to see when I asked the previous tech to show me the images from the diagnositc mammogram I had just had before they took me to the US area. The US showed some things that the mammogram did not.  I've been through so much with my sister since August. Her oncologist visits, chemo, 5 hospitalizations for infection, etc. She's given me all the details since day one. Although this is certainly a new perspective for me, I'm somewhat familiar with the terminology. I knew what a sentinel node biopsy is before he mentioned it, because her 3rd biopsy was a SNB, and I looked into it. The pamphlet that the Nurse Program Manager says the the US-guided core biopsy will take about 30 minutes. She said the that what I'll be having will take 60-90 minutes. I should expect to be there for approximately 4 hours total. When she told that I would be having the US-guided core biopsy and sentinel node biopsy, she was reading from the radiolotist's instructions/orders. Perhaps she was mistaken. I know anything is possible. She also told me at that time that my next step would probably be a lumpectomy, and she set up an appointment with a surgeon. That indicated to me that the radiologist has very little doubt that it's cancer. Guiding new patients through this part of the process is her full time job. She said if I have questions about anything at all, including support groups, seeing a nutritionist, whatever ~ call her and she would set up for me anything I need. And she is an R.N. The letters after her name are RN, BSN, CBPN-IC. I'm not sure what that last one stand for. The facility I went to is known for excellent care. It's part of a University teaching hospital, and has a highly regarded Cancer Center. The Cancer Center has two locations. One downtown on the University campus in the University hospital.The other is in the building where I had my mammogram and US. I chose to go there because they're nationally known for excellent care. As long as I'm in Madison, they seem like the place to go if there's a possibility of cancer of any type. The surgeon she scheduled me with is also my sister's surgeon. The radiologist was a male, looked to be late 30s or early 40s, so I'm guessing he's quite experienced. The Nurse Program Manager is the manager of Breast Care Services for the University hospital. All new breast cancer patients go through her. After my US, I was taken to her office to schedule the biopsy, the appt with the surgeon, and to talk about what to expect next. I think that's everything. I hope that didn't sound argumentative. I didn't say all of that to say I absolutely know what I'm talking about. I do know some of the terminology, procedures, ins and outs of the breast cancer treatment process.  But obviously I still have a lot to learn. I say all of this so that if any of you can see a breakdown in communication somewhere, or if it appears that I misunderstood/misinterpreted something, you can let me know. Honestly, the most important thing to me is accuracy. I don't care if the news is good or bad, just get it right. So if I have misinterpreted something, I really want to know. All of that being said, the radiologist believes that there's about a 95% chance that it's cancer. I understand that I won't know for sure until about 48 hours after the biopsy. Until then, I'm aware that the 5% chance that it's not cancer is very real, and that the biopsy may result in very good news. Sorry if I come off as unemotional and too matter of fact. That's pretty much how I talk in every day life, except when I talk to my animals :)   I'm so thankful for every word of input that you have all provided. Seriously, I may have misunderstood something, and if you notice anything that seems off, please point it out to me. I will call the Nurse Program Manager tomorrow and ask about the SNB. Possibly she meant that if I do indeed need a lumpectomy, it would be done at that time. Does that make more sense? I know she said it would be done, and I'm quite sure she said it would be at the same time as the core biopsy. I could be wrong about the timing. Sorry for the epic novel! :)
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 05:40AM dreniger wrote: I will definitely call and check tomorrow. The tracer dye procedure and removal of one node, the sentinel node, is exactly what was explained to me. I figured that's why she said the biopsy procedure would take 60-90 minutes, as opposed to 30 as described in the pamphlet about core biopsy. The addition of the SNB would account for the longer time for the procedure than just the core biopsy alone. They definitely did not talk about fine needle aspiration of an enlarged lymph node. She quite thoroughly explained the dye procedure and how it would determine which lymph node is considered the sentinel. I was told to wear a very supportive bra for the biopsy appointment, and I would be sent home with an ice pack, which I would need to use along with a very supportive bra for the first 24 hours, then just the very supportive bra for 5-7 days. Is this normal following a core biopsy? Is it normal following SNB? Everything seemed pretty clear when I left UW on Friday. I took pretty thorough notes. Now I'm confused because what I was told would happen apparently is not the norm. I could have asked more questions, but she seemed to be quite clear in her explanation.  Beacon800, if this were proposed to you, why would you turn it down flat? Do you mean that you would turn it down if it were offered in the context of core biopsy, or would you turn it down in any circumstance? Or are you saying that you'd turn it down before you had an actual diagnosis, and then have it done during surgery? As confident as the radiologist was, it sounded like he thought a SNB at this time was reasonable. He sounded as if the core biopsy was just to confirm what he already knew. I've spent so much time in the Cancer Center, talking to oncologists in the oncology unit of the hospital during my sister's hospitalizations, I really wasn't nervous during the mammogram or ultrasound, so I wasn't shaky or out of it during this conversation, nor the one with the Nurse Program Manager. The atmosphere is pretty much like what I've been living since September. But I'd like to be more informed before I make the phone call tomorrow. If this is something that's unnecessarily risky, I'd like to know. I guess what I'll ask is if the plan is actually for a SNB along with the core biopsy, and if so, why? She said that the procedure would take 60-90 minutes, and that I would be there for approximately 4 hours. Is that normal for a core biopsy? For a lumpectomy, she said I would go in early in the morning, and should be able to leave that evening. Other than telling me that a lumpectomy would likely be the next step, that it would be outpatient, and how long it would take, she didn't say anything about the procedure itself. I figured we'd cross that bridge when we come to it, if necessary. So...crap. I thought I knew exactly what would be happening on Monday. Now I'm wondering if I misuderstood what at the time seemed very straightforward. At any rate, tomorrow I'll find out for sure. Whether they do SNB or not, I want to know going in. I don't like surprises.And I'm thinking for future appointments I should take a small recorder. I'm so used to taking notes at every appointment my sister has ~ every hospitalization, every visit with her oncologist, every chemo, every trip to the ER ~ that I'm assuming I can do it objectively at my own appointments as well. Maybe I'm wrong about that. I recognize that that's entirely possible.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 04:57PM - edited Jan 31, 2012 04:58PM by dreniger Thank you for the explanation. I'm waiting for a return call from the Program Manager. After I talk to her, I'll know whether the SNB would actually be done during the later surgery, if necessary. I can see how that makes more sense. I'm wondering if we discussed the biopsy, then the possible surgery, then the biopsy again and I didn't realize we had switched back to the biopsy discussion. At any rate, it does look like I misunderstood somewhere along the line. I believe the biopsy is being done by the radiologist. I'll confirm that when I talk to the PM. I don't believe I'll meet the surgeon until my appointment with her on 2/13, a week after the biopsy.  Thanks for taking the time to check back, and to give an explanation. This is exactly the sort of thing that's helpful, and that I was hoping to find here.  [edited to correct spelling]
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 07:30AM dreniger wrote: I'm having BMX tomorrow morning, and the decision to not have recon was an easy one for me. I know without a doubt that I don't want the risks and possible complications of further surgeries. I have no problem with body image, and I'm confident that this will not change simply because I won't have breasts. After having cancer removed, the last thing I want to do is have something foreign implanted in my body. My sister made a different choice, and apparently it's a good choice for her. She's very comfortable with it, and what I've chosen is very alarming to her. It's such a personal decision, and one that only we can make for ourselves. No one else has to feel comfortable with it. I wish you the very best, whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: satisfaction with mastectomy only - no recontruction Papyrus 11BC

Posts.Content: dreniger wrote: My bilateral mastectomy was Feb 29, 2012. I'm unhappy with the lumpy results. I look like I had breast reduction, rather than mastectomy. I told my surgeon that I wanted flat, smooth results. Unfortunately, that's not what I got. I'm perfectly fine with being flat, but I don't like having what looks like small boobs, not quite in the right places. I think if they were where breasts belong it wouldn't be so bad. But one is higher, and they're different sizes.  According to my BS, I need to wait at least a year before further surgery. She said I could have liposuction to removed the fatty tissue that she left behind. Has anyone else had this done, and did you have to wait a year? It's only been 6 months, and I am still fairly tender. But I was thinking maybe by the end of Fall I would be ready. It seems like I shouldn't be in a hurry, but every time I look in the mirror and see the weird bumps, it bothers me. So does the cleavage. Why do I have cleavage after a BMX? Ugh. I psyched myself up to be flat, and I'm thrilled to not have to wear a bra. But with the lumpiness, I feel like I need one to smooth things out.  I just thought of something else. I'm quite overweight (losing now). Typically, the first place I lose weight is in my boobs (in the past). Is there a chance that as I lose weight these will go away without surgery? If so, I'm thinking they won't go entirely. When I have surgery, I'll have dog ears removed, too. But if it weren't for the small non-boobs, I wouldn't bother having the dog ears removed. Those I could live with. Denise Dx 2/7/2012, ILC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 2/29/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 4/17/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 7/13/2012 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy plastic surgery dreniger June56

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 05:43PM dreniger wrote: Excellent, Stacey! Have a glorious weekend :)
Posts.Title: biopsy today, scared rezski Thatgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2012 06:18AM - edited Mar 24, 2012 06:21AM by dreniger My bmx was 2/29. It actually looks like I had breast reduction rather than a mastectomy. I actually have a bit of cleavage. I wore a C cup before surgery, and now I look like an A cup with no nipples. I'm mortified. I initially thought it was swelling or fluid, and would go away in a few days. Apparently I was wrong. A week before surgery, I told my BS I was very confident about not wanting reconstruction. I followed up with an email, to specifically discuss dog ears. I told her I wanted to avoid them if at all possible, and to NOT leave excess tissue for the possibility of reconstruction at a later time. I also said I wanted the most flat, smoothest scar possible. Her response was that without reconstruction, she didn't know if dog ears could be avoided. I wish now that I would have taken that as a warning sign, and looked for another surgeon. These are not small bumps. I really look like I have breasts, minus nipples. I definitely need surgery to clean this up, which is exactly what I wanted to avoid. Not happy!
Posts.Title: Dog Ears? lisa-e debiann
